What Asylum Application Procedures Await Ukrainians?

All Ukrainians who are interested in filling in an application for international protection are eligible to do so, with all the rights as well as obligations related to such status.

Ukrainians who plan to make an asylum application are eligible to remain in the territory of the Member State, including at the border or transit areas, during the time the asylum procedure is provided with detailed information in a language that the applicant understands.

Once the application for international protection is made, it must be registered, which means registering the applicant’s purpose to seek asylum in EU countries. Then EU countries must show which authorities are responsible for registering asylum applications under national law.

Competent authorities in EU countries are obliged to ensure that applicants have the opportunity to lodge the request as soon as possible.

“EU countries must designate which authorities are responsible for the lodging of asylum applications under national law (Article 6(1) APD). If, however, a person refrains from lodging their application, the determining authority may take a decision to discontinue the procedure,” the European Agency for Asylum notes.

However, the rules may differ within EU countries after some Member States may set additional rules for persons interested in applying for asylum.

Applicants Should Be Informed When Applying for International Protection

After applying for international protection, the applicant should be informed at least of the following:

The procedure to be followed

Their obligations and rights during the procedure

The potential consequences of not complying with the obligations and not cooperating with the relevant authorities

The time frame of the examination process

The means at the applicant’s disposal for meeting the requirement to submit the elements to substantiate their asylum application

The possible consequences of an explicit or implicit withdrawal of the application.

As soon as a person who applied for international protection is required to lodge the request after the registration phase, the applicant should be provided with detailed information on how and where to lodge the petition, as well as the consequences of not lodging the application.

“It is essential that applicants are provided with information to ensure a fair and effective asylum procedure. Applicants should know their rights and obligations and understand the different stages of the procedure to present their claims as completely as possible and to comply with their obligations,” the Agency emphasises.

It is also important that Ukrainians interested in international protection in EU countries get informed and understand the stages of the request filed for asylum.

Intention as well as an expected outcome of the registration

Confidentiality in the international protection procedure

Registration procedure for asylum is free of charge

Practical steps during the registration process

Procedures to determine the European Union country responsible for examining the request filed for asylum

Document revealing the status of the applicant

How and where to lodge the application for asylum if the registration and the lodging are conducted separately

Soon after, a registration interview is organised.

“A registration interview is organised to collect reliable data from an applicant at the beginning of the procedure. As you may be the first person representing the asylum procedure who the applicant meets, it is important to approach the interview with a neutral attitude to enhance cooperation, establish an atmosphere of trust and provide information that is correct,” the Agency notes.

Citizens of Ukraine who plan to seek asylum in the EU countries are encouraged to provide all the necessary documents to the authorities in order to determine or verify their identity and nationality.

“Such documents include identity and travel documents (namely an identification card and/or passport), family documents (e.g. a family booklet, birth certificates, death certificates and/or marriage certificates), documents related to residence and travel routes and any documentary evidence that could support the asylum claim (e.g. a membership card to a claimed political or civil society organisation or a warrant of arrest)”, the Agency stressed.

In addition, applicants are urged to hand in their original documents. If the person who applies for asylum does not have the original documents but has copies, they are urged to tell the reason why the original document is not available and how the applicant was eligible to obtain copies of these documents.

As for the biometric data collected during the registration and lodging stage, it includes photographs as well as fingerprints. Depending on the national setup, there can be collected additional types of biometric data, including iris scan or voice recording.

Within a period of three days of filing in a request for asylum, the applicant must be provided with a document or asylum application card free of charge, which shows the applicant’s status for asylum and testifies that they are permitted to remain in the European Union country, in which they have applied for asylum while their application is being examined.

More countries in the European Union issue the application period for a specific period of time, after which it will be renewed if the person making the request is still authorised to remain in the country.

“Subsequent application means a further application for international protection made after a final decision has been taken on a previous application, including cases where the applicant has explicitly withdrawn his or her application and cases where the determining authority has rejected an application following its implicit withdrawal in accordance with Article 28,” the statement notes.

Number of Asylum Applications in EU Countries Filed by Ukrainians

According to the figures provided by the European Asylum Support Office EASO in 2021, a total of 5,301 first time asylum applications have been filed by Ukrainians in EU countries, while there were no repeated applications registered.

The figures published by EASO also revealed that 480 Ukrainians had refugee status, in November 2021, a total of 491 had the subsidiary protection status, while there were issued a total of 7,353 negative decisions.

EASO data also shows that the number of first-time applications filed by Ukrainians in EU countries in 2020, was 4,944, while in 2019, before the spread of the Coronavirus and its new strains, the number was 8,091.

While in 2014, the number of first time applications filed by Ukrainians in EU countries was 13,745, in the following year, in 2015, the first time application number reached its peak, during which year a total of 19,585 applications for asylum were registered by asylum authorities in EU countries.

As the U.S. and Europe impose sanctions, some in Latin America applaud Russia's Ukraine moves

Happening Today

This week, all eyes continue to be on Ukraine and what Vladimir Putin will do next as Russia appears on the brink of a full-scale invasion.

The U.S. and its allies, including the EU, Australia and Japan, have begun to roll out penalties largely aimed at Russian banks, sovereign debt and elites, as President Joe Biden on Tuesday called Putin’s moves “the beginning of a Russian invasion of Ukraine” and warned of further sanctions. Earlier today, Ukraine moved to declare a state of emergency and urged its citizens to leave Russia immediately as the situation escalates.

Russia, for its part, has remained defiant. Russian Ambassador to the U.S. Anatoly Antonov dismissed the sanctions, arguing that Russia has learned to live with sanctions and the new ones will hurt global financial and energy markets. “It is hard to imagine that there is a person in Washington who expects Russia to revise its foreign policy under a threat of restrictions,” he said.

Marking Defenders of the Fatherland Day, Putin said today that Moscow is still open to diplomacy, but underscored it will continue to increase its defense capacity. “Russia’s interests and the security of its citizens are unconditional,” Putin said, according to Russian state news agency TASS.

In Ukraine, Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba today called the coordinated sanctions “first decisive steps,” but urged allies to do more: “[T]he pressure needs to step up to stop Putin. Hit his economy and cronies. Hit more. Hit hard. Hit now.”

EU STANDS AS ONE: Persuading the EU — a group of 27 member states with distinctive priorities and politics — to agree to anything, particularly on something as sensitive as sanctions, is always an uphill battle. But the EU on Tuesday finally agreed on a package of sanctions to punish Russia.

As with the U.K. and the U.S., it’s only a first step — Brussels is still holding back from imposing its full suite of sanctions, which the Commission has drawn up until there is a further escalation.

In a hastily convened meeting, EU foreign ministers on Tuesday in Paris agreed to specific measures linked to Russia’s incursion into the two east Ukrainian enclaves of Donetsk and Luhansk. This includes targeting 351 members of the Duma (Russian parliament) and sanctions on 27 individuals and entities.

“This package of sanctions will hurt Russia and will hurt a lot," says EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell announcing the deal. But he conceded that there could be further meetings — and sanctions — to come. "We are afraid ... that this story has not finished," he said ominously.

Saying it as it is … and deleting it: In a tweet, Borrell said the sanctions mean there will be “no more … shopping in Milan, partying in Saint Tropez” or purchasing "diamonds in Antwerp." Borrell later deleted it but not before the Russian Foreign Ministry captured a screenshot and criticized him for “celebrating damage done by Brussels to businesses in EU Member-States.”

GERMANY BLINKS: But the big surprise was the decision by Germany to suspend the Nord Stream 2 Russia-to-Germany natural gas pipeline — a move the country had refused to commit to in recent weeks. Speaking at a news conference in Berlin, Chancellor Olaf Scholz said that Putin’s decision to order troops into the Donbas region had been a game-changer. “The situation today is fundamentally different,” he said.

It also reflects heavy American pressure. German officials had been lobbying members of Congress in Washington for months, and Biden had made no secret of his view on the matter. The fact that Germany is still receiving gas — for the moment at least — from the Nord Stream 1 pipeline may have softened the blow.

Russian warning: Nonetheless, in a sign of what may be to come for Europe’s energy supply — and pricing, Russia’s former president Dmitry Medvedev tweeted: “Welcome to the brave new world where Europeans are very soon going to pay €2,000 for 1,000 cubic metres of natural gas!”



MORE EU LEADERS’ MEETINGS TO COME: Rumors abound in Brussels that an emergency EU leaders’ summit could be called as early as Thursday if things continue to escalate and the EU decides to trigger its broader batch of sanctions.

MOSCOW LOOKS TO COURT LATIN AMERICA: Meanwhile, Russia hasn’t only had its sights on Ukraine. In recent weeks, the Kremlin has been playing up diplomacy in a region thousands of miles away from Moscow: Latin America.

In a clear display of Russia looking to increase its influence in the region, Russia's Deputy Prime Minister Yuri Borisov last week paid a visit to officials in Cuba, Venezuela and Nicaragua, including Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro, in a bid to deepen ties. Meanwhile, Brazil’s President Jair Bolsonaro flew to Moscow to meet with Putin last week — just days after Argentina’s President Alberto Fernández did the same.

And as expected, leaders in Cuba, Venezuela and Nicaragua — all antagonists to the U.S. with authoritarian, socialist regimes — have been quick to express support for Russia and its invasion of Ukraine. Nicaragua’s Daniel Ortega argued Ukraine’s effort to join NATO was a threat to Russia and “Russia is simply defending itself.” Cuba’s Foreign Minister Bruno Rodríguez rejected “the media and propaganda hysteria triggered by the US government against Russia.” Prior to the invasion, Maduro last week pledged “powerful military cooperation” with Russia.

Meanwhile, Brazil and Argentina have kept a more tepid tone on the crisis. At the United Nations Security Council meeting Monday, Brazil urged for negotiations but refused to mention Russia by name. Argentina’s Foreign Ministry issued a statement Tuesday expressing “worry” over the situation in Ukraine and calling for “diplomatic negotiations.” It did not mention Russia by name, either.

“Latin America has a very well-honed sense of sovereignty and non-intervention, which they routinely ring before U.S. audiences … but where is that same sensitivity when it comes to Russia bullying a weaker neighbor?” said Eric Farnsworth, vice president of the think tank Council of the Americas, adding how he has not seen much forceful condemnation coming out of the region on Putin’s moves.

Latin America ultimately isn’t a “strategic location for Russia,” Farnsworth said, but he still expects more engagement to come in the region. “It is a convenience for them. If they can harass U.S. interests … if they can make our lives less convenient by stirring things up in the region, they’re going to be willing to do that.”

EU PREPARING FOR CYBER WAR: The EU is deploying a team of cybersecurity experts to help Ukraine fight off cyberattacks. The EU’s Cyber Rapid Response Team includes around 10 national cybersecurity officials from six European countries — Croatia, Estonia, Lithuania, the Netherlands, Poland and Romania — who can provide assistance to countries under cyberattack.

European officials from those countries will work out the details with Ukraine on how many and which experts it will devote to the operation. Sending the cyber team into Ukraine “is an option we’re considering,” said Margiris Abukevičius, vice minister at the Ministry of National Defense in Lithuania, adding it will depend on the type of support Ukraine requests.

Ukraine has faced cyberattacks — often from Russian security services and hacking groups — for years, and the EU has poured millions into schemes supporting Ukraine’s cybersecurity and digital infrastructure in past years. But rising tensions between Kyiv and Moscow have set off a spate of cyberattacks on Ukraine in past weeks.

BETTER U.S.-HONDURAS TIES TO COME?: Less than a month ago, Honduras swore in the country’s first female president, Xiomara Castro. Just over a week ago, Honduran authorities detained former president Juan Orlando Hernández, once a U.S. ally, after Washington requested his extradition over drug trafficking charges.

So far, U.S. officials and experts on the region are viewing the new leadership in the Central American country as a new opportunity for cooperation with the U.S. on an array of issues, including tackling the reasons why thousands of Hondurans flee their country and make the trek north to the U.S. southern border each year.

“Castro has always been skeptical of the U.S., but all of a sudden there’s a convergence of interests … and the U.S. is trying to see if she’s serious about fighting corruption and can develop a real working relationship with her government,” Andrew Selee, president of the nonpartisan Migration Policy Institute, told us. “They see it as a moment of opportunity that they have to seize, but there’s an awareness that the relationship is still fragile.”
